column1:
A boil order in Algonquin that spanned much of this weekend has been lifted.Â 

The village of Algonquin initially issued a 24-hour precautionary boil order Friday for the areas near Huntington Drive east of Hanson Road to Holly Lane. On Saturday, the boil order was issued for another 24 hours.Â 

Late Sunday, the village posted to its website that the boil order had been lifted.Â 

The village of Algonquin has a map of the area that had been affected by the boil order.Â 

The Illinois Environmental Protection Agency was notified regarding the boil order.

During the course of the boil order, those living in area affected were advised to boil all water used for drinking, cooking and even water used to brush their teeth.Â 

They were also asked to turn off the water supply to their icemaker.Â Â If the icemaker couldn't be turned off, residents in the affected area are asked to throw out all of the ice made until 24 hours after the boil order has been lifted.

Additional information will be made available online atÂ www.algonquin.org.Â 

Were you affected by this weekend's boil order? Tell us in the comments' section.Â 

Source: village of Algonquin websiteÂ

Water main break causes Boone County boil advisory

by Jennifer Weiser
column2:
body=You%20should%20read%20this!%0A%0Ahttp://krcgtv.com/news/local/water-main-break-causes-boone-county-boil-advisory"">
Sat, 09 Jun 2012 03:06:03 GMT âÂ 


There is a boil advisory for part of Boone County due to a water main break. It effects customers of Public Water Supply District No. 10 of Boone County on Barnes Road, McLain Dailing, Farwest School Road, Dowell Road, Wallace School Road and Lost Woods.


Those effective are asked to bring all water that is to be consumed to a rolling boil for five minutes, turn off water softeners and do not use ice from automatic ice cube makers.


The advisory goes until 3pm on Tuesday, June 12th. If you have any questions, please call 573-682-5314.

The boil water order in the area of Belvedere Road and South Dixie Highway has been lifted, West Palm Beach officials report.
A water main break early Wednesday prompted the order and closed Belvedere Road east of Dixie Highway for a couple days. But the water main and the road have been repaired and the road is again open.
The boil water order included the 300-700 blocks of Belvedere Road.

<i>Customers in Bedminster, Chester Township, Far Hills,
Peapack-Gladstone, Pottersville, and Tewksbury can resume normal water
New Jersey American Water has rescinded its precautionary boil water
advisory for its customers in sections of Bedminster, Chester Township,
Far Hills, Peapack-Gladstone, Pottersville, and Tewksbury. Customers no
longer have to boil their water. Testing has concluded that the water
meets or exceeds state and federal guidelines.
It is no longer necessary to boil your water before consumption
however, the following measures are strongly encouraged at this time:
Run your water faucets for 3-5 minutes to flush your service
connection and interior plumbing with water from the service main.
Empty and clean your automatic ice makers and water chillers.
Drain and refill your hot water heater if the temperature is set below
Service connections with a water softener/cartridge filters should be
run through a regeneration cycle or other procedures recommended by
Water reservoirs in tall buildings should be drained and refilled.
The precautionary boil water alert was issued late Sunday after a broken
water line shut down the company's Bedminster booster station, which
maintains water pressure for the approximately 1,400 customers impacted.
The advisory is a standard precaution issued whenever water pressure is
Repairs to New Jersey American Water's Bedminster booster station are
nearing completion and the station should be fully operational by the
evening of Wednesday, June 13. Customers no longer need to take extra
water conservation measures and can resume normal water use.
New Jersey American Water thanks its customers for their patience during
the boil water advisory and for their cooperation in conserving water
while repairs were being made to the booster station.
New Jersey American Water, a wholly owned subsidiary of American Water
(NYSE: AWK), is the largest investor-owned water utility in the state,
providing high-quality and reliable water and/or wastewater services to
approximately 2.5 million people. Founded in 1886, American Water is the
largest publicly traded U.S. water and wastewater utility company. With
headquarters in Voorhees, N.J., the company employs more than 7,000
dedicated professionals who provide drinking water, wastewater and other

Hamburg boil-water advisory likely until Wednesday
Hamburg officials expect a boil-water advisory for borough customers to be in place until Wednesday.
The advisory was issued Monday because of insufficient chlorine in the borough's primary well.
The borough recommends that customers boil tap water for a minute before drinking it. Failing to do so could result in diarrhea, cramps, nausea and headaches, according to the advisory.

Routine water samples taken Monday morning revealed that no chlorine was left in the well, even though a scale indicated on Friday that there were 17 pounds remaining, said Keith Brobst, water and wastewater superintendent. The chlorine is used to rid the water of bacterial contamination.
Further analysis showed that water was running without chlorine for two hours Monday morning before the problem was discovered, Brobst said.
Brobst said Monday afternoon that he's confident the advisory will be lifted Wednesday.
Never say never, but I sampled throughout the system today and I don't anticipate any problem,"" he said.

New Jersey American Water has issued a precautionary boil water advisory
for its customers in sections of Bedminster, Chester Township, Far
Hills, Peapack-Gladstone, Pottersville, and Tewksbury. On Sunday
morning, a broken water line shut down the company's Bedminster booster
station, which maintains water pressure for approximately 1,400
customers whose water service was interrupted or who experienced low
Please note <b>that this is a standard procedure whenever water pressure
is lost as a precaution.Â New Jersey American Water will provide
information as to when the advisory is lifted.
<i><b>The New Jersey Department of Environmental Protection requires
that the company issue the following advisory:
New Jersey American Water has determined that a potential or actual
threat to the quality of water being provided to you currently exists.
Therefore until further notice, bring tap water to a rolling boil for
one minute and allow to cool before using for consumption
cubes, washing vegetables and fruit, and for brushing teeth. Please
continue to boil your water until you are notified that the water
New Jersey American Water also recommends the following steps:
Throw away uncooked food or beverages or ice cubes if made with tap
water during the day of the advisory
Keep boiled water in the refrigerator for drinking
Rinse hand-washed dishes for a minute in diluted bleach (one
tablespoon of household bleach per gallon of tap water) or clean your
dishes in a dishwasher using the hot wash cycle and dry cycle.
Do not swallow water while you are showering or bathing
Provide pets with boiled water after cooling
Do not use home filtering devices in place of boiling or using bottled

customers immediately when the advisory is lifted.
New Jersey American Water is working around the clock to repair its
Bedminster booster station and restore normal water service, which may
take several days. In the meantime, the company has implemented
temporary pumping measures to the impacted areas. While work continues,
customers are asked to conserve water inside and outside of their homes.
For those without water, the company has established a water station at
the Peapack Municipal Building at 1 School St. in Peapack where impacted
customers can fill water jugs or receive bottled water. The water
station will be in operation until all regular water pressure is
restored to all customers in the effected areas.
